title: Thursday Murder Club 2 – Helen Mirren speaks out on The Man Who Died Twice movie
description: Dame Helen Mirren has spoken out on The Thursday Murder Club 2, which would be a film adaptation of Richard Osman's second novel, The Man Who Died Twice.
content:
Following last night’s London premiere, the film adaptation of Richard Osman’s novel, The Thursday Murder Club, is now out in cinemas ahead of its Netflix debut next week. Despite a lukewarm reception in the reviews, the Steven Spielberg-produced film will undoubtedly be a hit on the streaming service as a cosy watch at home. And so comes the inevitable question of, will there be a Thursday Murder Club 2? Dame Helen Mirren, who stars as retired MI6 spy Elizabeth, told the Radio Times: “[I’d do another] in a nanosecond. And it would be the team getting back together, which would be great. “We did have a wonderful time shooting this. So all of us would jump at the chance, quite honestly.”

Given Netflix’s success with Rian Johnson’s Knives Out murder mysteries starring Daniel Craig’s Benoit Blanc, we’d expect there to be plenty more from the Thursday Murder Club. After all, there are four more of Osman’s books and counting to adapt, starting with the second novel The Man Who Died Twice. The book’s synopsis reads: “In The Man Who Died Twice, the Thursday Murder Club gets back into action when someone Elizabeth used to know comes looking for help. He's in hiding after being accused of stealing millions in diamonds from a man known for his connections to the criminal underworld. When dead bodies soon start piling up, these crime-solving pensioners must kick things into high gear, figure out who's behind off of this and hopefully locate some shiny diamonds as well.”

After The Man Who Died Twice, Mirren, Pierce Brosnan, Sir Ben Kingsley and Celia Imrie could also return in The Bullet That Missed, The Last Devil to Die and the upcoming fifth story, The Impossible Fortune, which is published on September 25. The Thursday Murder Club is out now in select cinemas and will be streaming on Netflix from August 28.
summary: The film adaptation of Richard Osman's novel, The Thursday Murder Club, is currently in cinemas and will debut on Netflix next week. Despite mixed reviews, the film is expected to be a hit on the streaming service. Dame Helen Mirren, who stars as retired MI6 spy Elizabeth, expressed her desire for a sequel to the film, stating that she would "enjoy" shooting the film and would "gloat" with the team.
shortSummary: The Thursday Murder Club, starring Helen Mirren, is out in cinemas and will debut on Netflix next week, with the possibility of a sequel.

The Thursday Murder Club’s Helen Mirren reveals "real chemistry" with co-star: "Pierce is my wonderful late discovery"
Helen Mirren says that filming The Thursday Murder Club was a magical moment in her career.
This article first appeared in Radio Times magazine.
Was making The Thursday Murder Club as much fun as it looks?
It was a wonderful coming together of the tribe – one of those magical moments in a career. Ben and I started out together in the Royal Shakespeare Company, both ambitious and obsessed. Celia and I became really good friends on Calendar Girls [2003]. I didn’t know Pierce before making this and the Paramount+ series MobLand, but we both did street theatre before he went off and became a massive movie star with James Bond. There was a synchronicity.
How did you and Pierce behave with each other on those two different shoots?
They are totally different characters, but Pierce and I have a very similar way of working, which is serious without being too serious about ourselves. Neither of us is what you would call a method actor. We find a nice, comfortable seat to sit in with our scripts and just chill together. Pierce is my wonderful late discovery. I’d like to work with Pierce for the rest of my life. I feel that we have a real chemistry.
Is sexual attraction a necessary part of that on-screen chemistry?
There is a bit of that in there, but it’s never the whole thing. Strangely, people with great sexual attraction to each other off-screen can have absolutely nothing on-screen. It’s very weird. And people who really don’t like each other off- screen can have this amazing sexual attraction that the audience can perceive. I guess viewers misread the loathing that they have for each other in real life as a frisson of attraction.
Is Elizabeth’s steeliness, as you portray her, protection against her fear of ageing?
Possibly. Elizabeth’s loss of her dear friend in The Thursday Murder Club is intrinsic to the story and it’s heartbreaking. And as you get older, like me, you must confront these tragedies. They come in the most unexpected of ways: sometimes it’s not the person you expect to lose that you lose. You have no idea what’s coming down the line, but it’s getting closer and closer. You could seriously get your knickers in a twist about that, but you just can’t.
Would you be game to get involved in more Thursday Murder Club adventures?
In a nanosecond. And it would be the team getting back together, which would be great. We did have a wonderful time shooting this. So all of us would jump at the chance, quite honestly.

Helen Mirren, who stars in the film, expressed enthusiasm for returning to the role, indicating that the cast would eagerly participate in future adaptations.
